file_metadata.title: Microfluidic Platform to Study Intercellular Connectivity Through On-chip Electrical Impedance Measurement

chunks.text: A platform has been developed to study intercellular communication in non-neural cells as it relates to developmental biology and morphogenetic bioengineering. The platform uses laminar flow in a microfluidic channel to create a “sucrose gap" that forces electrical signaling through a cell monolayer. Intercellular communication is detected through electrical impedance measurements. A phase sensitive homodyne system has been designed and simulated in a 130nm CMOS process to provide a readout of cell monolayer complex impedance within the device. The system exhibits a highly linear conversion rate of 0.589mV/kΩ for cell layer impedances up to 1 ΜΩ.
chunks.chunk_summary: A microfluidic platform with integrated impedance measurement allows for studying intercellular communication in non-neural cells.

chunks.text: Non-neural cells possess sophisticated intercellular communication mechanisms mediated by gap junctions, which are close cytosolic couplings allowing the exchange of signaling molecules or ions between adjacent cells. These gap junctions, comprised of membrane proteins, play a crucial role in shaping cell development, impacting pattern formation, asymmetry, and organ growth. Errors in gap junction signaling can lead to abnormal growth and diseases like cancer. Regulation of these electrical synapses is essential for exploiting developmental bioelectricity for bioengineering artificial living constructs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Gap junctions mediate intercellular communication in non-neural cells and play a crucial role in development and disease.

chunks.text: Traditional methods for examining gap junction activity, such as patch clamping and dye diffusion, have limitations. Patch clamping disrupts the membrane and is technically challenging, while dye diffusion results are difficult to quantify and repeat. To overcome these limitations, a microfluidic platform is proposed for repeatable non-invasive assays on tissue networks. This platform electrically isolates a living cell culture, allowing precise impedance measurements that correspond to the average connectivity across the cells. This real-time monitoring enables closed-loop drug delivery studies to test training and anticipation in gap junction networks.
chunks.chunk_summary: Traditional methods for studying gap junctions have limitations, motivating the development of a new microfluidic platform.

chunks.text: The microfluidic device miniaturizes sucrose bridge experiments, using laminar flow to create three distinct fluid regions in a central channel. A sucrose-based center stream creates a high impedance barrier, forcing electrical signaling through the cell layer. Current stimulus driven between the conductive saline side streams traverses the cell monolayer, producing a recordable voltage representing the average electrical impedance across the cell network. Digitally controlled solenoid valves allow quick switching of the central stream among three high resistivity sucrose solutions, enabling closed-loop drug delivery experiments.
chunks.chunk_summary: The microfluidic device uses laminar flow and a sucrose gap to isolate and measure the impedance of a cell monolayer.

chunks.text: The PDMS top layer of the microchannels offers advantages such as reduced leakage, accommodation of fabrication tolerances, outgassing of trapped bubbles, and exceptional cell adhesion. The microfluidic chip fabrication involves patterning Cr/Au electrodes onto a borosilicate substrate, forming microfluidic channel walls using SU8-3050, and using a PDMS top layer. The layers are compressed in a custom acrylic housing designed for mounting on an inverted microscope.
chunks.chunk_summary: The microfluidic chip is fabricated using PDMS, SU8, and Cr/Au electrodes on a borosilicate substrate, housed in acrylic.

chunks.text: The device incorporates additional electrodes for a control channel and routes signals to a single edge for connection via a standard chip edge connector. This connector interfaces with a custom printed circuit board housing the integrated circuit for electrical impedance measurements.
chunks.chunk_summary: The device includes a control channel and connects to a custom PCB for impedance measurements.

chunks.text: In order to prevent electroplating of the electrodes and damage to the cell layer, the stimulus current must be an alternating current (AC). The system architecture, shown in Fig. 2, uses a homodyne detection scheme to measure the complex impedance of the cell monolayer. A sinusoidal stimulus current is driven across the cell layer and the resulting voltage is demodulated to extract the magnitude and phase of the impedance. The system is designed to operate at a frequency of 1 kHz, which is biologically relevant and avoids parasitic capacitances.
chunks.chunk_summary: A homodyne detection scheme is used to measure the complex impedance of the cell monolayer with an AC stimulus current at 1 kHz.

chunks.text: The current source is implemented using a modified Howland current pump, as shown in Fig. 3. This configuration allows for precise control of the stimulus current amplitude and frequency. The output impedance of the current source is high, ensuring that the current through the cell layer is independent of the cell impedance. The current source is designed to deliver a sinusoidal current with an amplitude of 1 μA, which is within the safe range for biological experiments.
chunks.chunk_summary: A modified Howland current pump is used as the current source, providing precise control and high output impedance.

chunks.text: The demodulator circuit, shown in Fig. 4, multiplies the measured voltage with in-phase and quadrature components of the stimulus signal. The resulting signals are then low-pass filtered to extract the real and imaginary parts of the cell impedance. The low-pass filters are implemented using active RC filters with a cutoff frequency of 100 Hz. The output of the demodulator is a DC voltage proportional to the magnitude and phase of the cell impedance.
chunks.chunk_summary: The demodulator circuit multiplies the measured voltage with the stimulus signal and filters the result to extract the real and imaginary parts of the impedance.

chunks.text: The system has been simulated in a 130nm CMOS process using Cadence Spectre. The simulation results show that the system exhibits a highly linear conversion rate of 0.589mV/kΩ for cell layer impedances up to 1 ΜΩ. The phase sensitivity of the system is also high, allowing for accurate measurement of the phase angle of the cell impedance. The overall performance of the system meets the requirements for studying intercellular communication in non-neural cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: Simulations in a 130nm CMOS process demonstrate a linear conversion rate and high phase sensitivity, meeting the requirements for studying intercellular communication.
